comments.text:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:6.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/6.0
Build ID: 20110811165603




Expected results:

Mozilla installer should add a Stand-alone installation (USB/portable) feature and option to the installer. This would certainly help people wanting to have sensitive data stored only on an encrypted drive or container ala TrueCrypt.

The profile should be located inside the install dir and nothing (unnecessary) should be written to the registry. See Opera for a nice implementation of this.

Would take the heat off these issues:
Bug 35308
Bug 98346
Bug 19184
Bug 16489

Not sure how we would add this to the existing UI which is getting overcrowded but we might be able to come up with something.

> The profile should be located inside the install dir and nothing
> (unnecessary) should be written to the registry. See Opera for a nice
> implementation of this.
The installer doesn't understand profiles. Something would likely need to be done in product to force that.

> Would take the heat off these issues:
> Bug 35308
> Bug 98346
> Bug 19184
> Bug 16489
Note: this bug would only apply to Firefox and several of those bugs are about mail. A Thunderbird and Seamonkey bug would also need to be filed for those products.

comments.raw_text:
just get a really simple batch-file for such purpose: https://github.com/Riajyuu/Portable-Firefox

Don't really get the point that this is still denied.

I marked this bug as P5, which as our documentation [0] explains, means that this is a low-priority issue that Mozilla will not be committing engineering resources to, but a patch from a contributor would be considered.

Implementing a portable mode that's complete enough to ship in Firefox is more complicated than just a batch file, and, especially with projects like PortableApps [1] already serving this need, it's just not a high priority.

[0] https://github.com/mozilla/bug-handling/blob/master/policy/triage-bugzilla.md#how-do-you-triage
[1] https://portableapps.com/apps/internet/firefox_portable
